Award.AwardTitle: Negative Refraction and Localized Resonance of Guided Elastic Waves

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to study backward wave propagation in elastic waveguides and how it can be harnessed to create novel acoustic wave devices and improved nondestructive evaluation techniques. The research approach is to determine the conditions under which backward waves exist in plates and thin films, and how to efficiently control wave propagation through mode conversion between forward and backward propagating waves at interfaces. Backward wave propagation can lead to non-intuitive physical effects such as negative refraction and negative reflection of elastic waves and localized resonances. Experimental measurements and computational modeling will be used to design and evaluate surface acoustic and plate wave lenses based on negative refraction, and to assess the potential for using negative reflection and localized resonances for the nondestructive evaluation of thin films and plates.

If successful, this research will lead to a new approach for manipulating guided elastic waves by controlling the surface profile of waveguides. Structures supporting guided elastic waves are commonplace and the results of the proposed research offer potential improvements to the nondestructive evaluation of aircraft, pipelines, and critical electronic components. Backward wave propagation could prove to be an enabling technology, offering a fundamentally new approach for the design of a wide range of acoustic devices including resonators, filters, and lenses. It could also have an impact on a broad range of fields that incorporate elastic wave propagation, from seismology to energy harvesting. The research will support advanced training for undergraduate and graduate students, and an education program will be developed where high school and undergraduate students are introduced to nondestructive testing through hands-on laboratory work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Backward wave propagation is broadly defined as wave propagation in which the wave energy propagates in one direction while the wave crests and troughs, specifying the phase velocity, proceed in the opposite direction. These waves are associated with intriguing physical processes and have received widespread interest in the acoustics and optics communities. It has long been known that finite, elastic structures such as rods, cylinders, and plates can support modes exhibiting backward wave propagation. While backward wave propagation is ubiquitous in simple elastic structures, it is only recently that the phenomenon has been harnessed for manipulating elastic waves and characterizing materials. In this research project, we have studied the physical origin of backward wave propagation in elastic waveguides, along with applications of backward waves in specific waveguide systems. We have shown that backward waves can exhibit unusual effects including negative reflection and negative refraction. These effects, in turn, allow for the creation of new acoustic devices and applications. The results of this project will have a broad impact on the field of nondestructive testing, where guided waves are used to detect defects in materials. Improved techniques for defect detection will lead to improved industrial productivity and can potentially save lives. The results will also enable the development of a new generation of acoustic devices such as resonators and filters. The project also led to the development of new educational demonstrations that were used to introduce students to the field of nondestructive testing, and supported the education of graduate students in this important discipline.
